TextBlock.TextLine: zo and end yett Iam not att all in corridged to remore my habitation
much less to medele with any of their correspondents most past of
of namier & there abouts denants venle reulemond weert a lest tath
Andernaere & ofall which I finde a xact accompts my brother
in Law beeng executeur of the orphants of the widdow, so that cbyhis
meanes I could have her ware house butt wee all dispose itt I amentred
for £400: sts ap in the stiff trade with in Ast as you
In Antwerp 13 maij 1681
London Iparis slaughter
Sr. I have recd. in due time yd of 15: past which I have also then accquainted to mr maynard
whilst I delayd to answer you my self till I had discoursed John peeters att brussels
where I have been last saturday, and after all I could prevaile boath with him
& mj assistance, is concluded that I could returne you for £200 A in resting
cloathes and the rest in mony this I could advise you to accept, and orders
the 2 bills to be delivered to mee with yd full discharge itt may be you will
not be so will iny to accept of the goods, butt mee thinks itt is not umreasonch
you should receave them because they are worth the valew now with yd
of their first cost, & you will be able to make their price for them where
as here they (principally & onely the yeallow cullours) can not be sold
so must intreat you to assist them here in & the sooner the better, for if
John Peeters should dye which is vere likely to be I doubt I should finde
more troubles & persecutions of other of his creditors, so this is all I can
say as to that att present & remaine
th
London Henry Collier
S. I have before mee yd of 18 & 29 past I delay answering because I finde solittee
hopes to recover any thingh from T.H. who doth yet worse then one that
is broake, for he hath lest house keeping here & what soever didin any regand
concerne him transported to his som & wise, besides wee have sent to him
to insimiates the sentence against him & wee never can finde, him the
answer beeng alwyes that he is out of towne, the lace hath allowed all
what wee can not finde the man, or non of his effects wee have had severall
consults with lawers about said bussynes, & all to litthe purpose, could wee butt
once arrest him I should be in hopes to recover some thingh m. Herrence
hath promised to keep care in the bussynes in which I could wish you was
more happy, then hetherto you have been thought you wonder that how
he could have spent all what he owes I do not in the least
now considdering what life he lived sence I knewhim, I am well informed
that he hath been sich to bed att least a month, butt now a rcovering: in case
yon be accquainted with one m. t puchle now come to london with
the saght of capt fasebyte, he will be able to give you afull acctt. of his concernes
yd bill for £100 I have accepted: as also that which you have mended & beeng
trgighned, have been obliged to serve mee of £63„5ƒ which this day
have drawne on you att 1½ uso att 35:7 payable to mr. Will sham brooke
for the valew of mr. lauwereys pauwels which please to accept & passt
yd acctt. I have examined the pattarnes of the 12 cloathes you bought
in case they prove well hope to sell them well to which be sare
of my endeavour butt you do not mention in what ship
you have shipper them and if any wrappers about the pack
which I exspett to know pr first, which I remaine
with kinde saluto
London Henry Maynard
In Antwarp 13 maij 168156
S. my last to you was on the 4: curitt sence non from you so this serve pertes
to covert of the inclosed letter to mr. slaughter, whom I could advise to accept
thementione preposition & desire yd assistance here in because I foind John peeters
in an ill condition, besides I would faine becleared of that concerne, for in case
he should due I might be troubled of others where as shall not in case I have
an adiustement sooner: I receaved this day our 5 bales by willard, butt this
impudent hath op ened some bales off ottons, and itt zeens as if the packers
that made them up againe betrayd as the 250p. of callicoes are lest behinde
& couts is gon thether, what he will be able to do I know nott, I have more
often wrott you that you should exspres in the bills of loading not to open any
goods whcch when they do, causes a great preiudice as by all apearence the callioes
should have passed, butt m. Scawen goeth onto furious, to many bales of one
sort in one vessel, so that is now att anend for the cherchers will visitt thecottons
hence for ward very close: you had order to send mee 2 blews lighter the the
first sent & you sent mee 2 asneare them that I can not distinguishany differ
rence boter wixt the 4 intheir cullour, in somick that they can not serve my
turne, inclosed the first accepted bill on mr. sanuel shepeard of whiel
have send you the second: next post you shall the acctt. of sale of last month
as also some remises. the exccutours of the widdow bouwens estate would fame sell
all their goods to one, which I could wish they did, that so they dous no
preiudice by selling by the candle to every one for besides that sall doth decrease
very much, itt would then be att a stand haveing no more to in large remainer
I finde yd bayes vrappers extrourdimary deare, & not worth their prijses so that I
I could advise you to take ⅓ of spanish cloathes to each pack now a providing
& wrapp them there wath
In Antwerp 13 maij 1681
London Abram vivian
th 5
S. my last to you was on the 7„ curitt, sence receaved yd of the 22 passato by
which I observe that the bayes a revery deare thought not so deare as they
have been, so hope you will finde our parcell to content, that sort of 1.C and
RK which in. Holroide wasused to send, is the very best I yett hadd & in
yd last parcell there was non, so hope you will send of themnow & that they
be shipped by this time, for pindar is longsence arrived & thomas smith a
loading att Hull bij sr which I exspect that some our in ordered cloathes
mais come as well as the bayes, of which exspect yd advise, as also patt
as soone as come to yd hand for my governo yd bill I have accepted & past
to yd acctt. & now shall hence for ward be a remitting as much I can
as to the laces sent you in N. 14 I hope will prove to yd contents for they
are all good chep inclosed is the invoyce for then which finding wright please
to note accordingly I do not know how &N13 should tarry so long by the way I hope
itt is now safe in yd custody: in case you finde any thingh cemonghst the laces
sent that will not sell you may returne itt & Ill putt itt off here for I have
been att brussell 3 dayes sence & they tell mee that open ground, or Holes are
still the most demandee for france, though plaine & lupeed ground by also
in faskion: I am no more engaged for one penny in laces haveing recd all
I had be spoaken & added what I tought should fitt the pariell, so in case
hence forward you want any more lett mee have yd ample & full instructions
beeng now in theway to buy all sorts & ascheap as can be afforded, for I buy
with ready mony upon thenaile & the best spetia wee have I ofserve
you had firinge againe in towne thought itt was over come, itt
zeems London is much menacced with fire, from which god preserve
in all
